_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This Risk Management Program is designed to comply with the Environmental Protection Agency regulations detailed in 40 CFR Part 68.  The stationary source is the Mississippi Beef Processing facility located at 10646 Hwy 51 N, Oakland, MS. It is owned by the Community Bank. The only RMP regulated substance in this facility is anhydrous ammonia--which is classified as a toxic substance, liquefied under pressure.

This is an RMP update for an existing ammonia refrigeration system in a beef processing facility.

The refrigeration system in this facility uses anhydrous ammonia as the refrigerant. This process does not meet the requirements of Program 1. It is subject to OSHA's PSM standard.  Therefore, this RMP is written to meet the EPA Program 3 level of compliance.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICY
This facility follows a rigorous RMP & Process Safety Management Program to prevent the accidental release of ammonia. The program is also in compliance with Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), Process Safety Management (PSM) of 29 CFR 1910.119. Employees and management participate and cooperate in the PSM & RMP programs to maintain a work environment that is safe to employees, the community, and the environment.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICY
The facility has a comprehensive emergency response plan that meets established criteria. The plan will be provided to the local LEPC for review.

PROCESS OVERVIEW
This food processing facility operates a multi-temperature, anhydrous ammonia (R-717) refrigeration system engine room capacities of +30?F high temperature suction, +15?F medium temperature suction, -20?F low temperature suction, and -42?F low temperature suction. This refrigeration system is a liquid re-circulating system and is designed to operate with an overfeed-ratio of approximately 3:1 for evaporative air units. Anhydrous ammonia (R-717) refrigerant is a Group II refrigerant. Rotary screw compressors are used in the refrigeration system. Engine room

electrical classification is NEMA-1.

This ammonia refrigeration system contains ten interconnected sub-systems:
1.Low-temperature re-circulating evaporator system (-42?F @ 9.81PSIA).
2.Low-temperature re-circulating evaporator system (-20?F @ 3.6 psig).
3.Medium-temperature evaporator system (+15?F @ 28.4 psig).
4.High-temperature evaporator system (+30?F @ 45.0 psig).
5.Thermosyphon pilot receiver system (95?F @ 181 psig).
6.Condenser system (95?F C.T. 80?F W.B.).
7.Compressor low-temperature system (-42?F @ 9.81PSIA).
8.Compressor low-temperature system (-20?F @ 3.6 psig).
9.Compressor medium-temperature system (+15?F @ 28.4 psig).
10.Compressor high-temperature system (+30?F @ 45.0 psig).

This system operates in part as a single-stage system and also a two-stage compression system. Twenty-three evaporative air-units and three water chillers operate at a +30 ?F suction temperature using the two-stage intercooler as a re-circulator vessel. Nine evaporative air-units operate at a +15 ?F suction temperature. Five evaporative air-units and one glycol chiller operate at a -20 ?F suction temperature. Six evaporative air-units operate at a -42 ?F suction temperature.

Refrigeration equipment includes:
?One low-temperature -42 ?F booster-compressor.
?One low-temperature -20 ?F booster-compressor.
?Two high-temperature +15 ?F compressors.
?Two high-temperature +30 ?F compressors. 
?One-Hansen APC Auto-Purger.
?One 30? dia. x 6?-0? thermosyphon pilot-receiver.
?One 60? dia. x 17?-10? high-pressure receiver.
?One 72" dia. x 13'-2" OAL intercooler  & vertical re-circulator package.
?One 48" dia. x 12'-2" OAL vertical re-circulator package.
?One 48" dia. x 12'-2" OAL vertical re-circulator package.
?One 48" dia. x 12'-2" OAL vertical re-circulator package.
?Three evaporative condensers.

The low-temperature re-circulator is a vertical pressure vessel. It operates a saturated liquid temperature of -42?F. The low-temperature liquid is pumped from this vessel to the blast free

zer air units where thirty- percent of the liquid mass is evaporated. The liquid-vapor mixture is returned to this vessel where the liquid is separated from the vapor. The low temperature compressors take the ammonia vapor from this vessel and compress it to approximately 45 PSIA. This vessel has connection with the low temperature compressors (dry suction) and with the low-temperature evaporators (wet suction and pumped liquid).

The low-temperature re-circulator is a vertical pressure vessel. It operates a saturated liquid temperature of -20?F. The low-temperature liquid is pumped from this vessel to the freezer air units where thirty- percent of the liquid mass is evaporated. The liquid-vapor mixture is returned to this vessel where the liquid is separated from the vapor. The low temperature compressors take the ammonia vapor from this vessel and compress it to approximately 45 PSIG. This vessel has connection with the low temperature compressors (dry suction) and with the low-temperature evaporators (wet suction and pumped liquid).

The medium-temperature re-circulator is a vertical pressure vessel. It operates a saturated liquid temperature of +15?F. The medium-temperature liquid is pumped from this vessel to the cooler air units where thirty- percent of the liquid mass is evaporated. The liquid-vapor mixture is returned to this vessel where the liquid is separated from the vapor. The medium-temperature compressors take the ammonia vapor from this vessel and compress it to approximately 181 PSIG. This vessel has connection with the medium-temperature compressors (dry suction), medium-pressure liquid piping , and with the medium-temperature evaporators (wet suction and pumped liquid).

The intercooler is a vertical pressure vessel. It operates at a saturated liquid temperature of +30?F. The low-stage booster-compressors discharge superheated vapor into this vessel. The superheated vapor bubbles up through liquid ammonia giving up its superheat and creating more

vapor volume. Liquid ammonia for the low-temperature loads is fed into this vessel and is cooled to saturation temperature. The medium-temperature liquid is pumped from this vessel to the medium-temperature air units where thirty- percent of the liquid mass is evaporated. The liquid-vapor mixture is returned to this vessel where the liquid is separated from the vapor. The high-temperature liquid is pumped from this vessel to the cooler air units where thirty- percent of the liquid mass is evaporated. The liquid-vapor mixture is returned to this vessel where the liquid is separated from the vapor.
The high-stage compressors pull ammonia vapor from this vessel and compress it to approximately 181 PSIG. This vessel has connection with low-stage booster-compressors, high-stage compressors, high-temperature air units, and with the high-pressure liquid piping.

The high-pressure receiver is a vertical pressure vessel. The high -pressure receiver stores the ammonia liquid from the condenser. The liquid enters the top of the vessel from the thermosyphon pilot-receiver and is maintained at compressor discharge pressure. This vessel has connection with the thermosyphon pilot-receiver, medium-temperature re-circulator vessel, and the high-temperature re-circulator vessel.

The evaporative condensers use axial fans in a draw-through configuration. High-pressure ammonia-vapor flows from the high-stage compressors to the evaporative condenser where heat is removed. The vapor is condensed into a high-pressure liquid using air and water flowing over the outside of the condensing pipe coils. High-pressure liquid from the condenser is drained to the thermosyphon pilot-receiver and overflows to the controlled-pressure receiver. The condenser has connections with the compressor discharge lined, the thermosyphon pilot-receiver, and the purger.

The evaporators are fed from liquid pumps on the re-circulator packages. The feed rate is approximately 3:1. This efficiency of this system is i

ncreased by circulating up to three times the amount of the refrigerant needed by the evaporator for the rated capacity. This system operates in part as a single-stage system and also a two-stage compression system. Twenty-three evaporative air-units operate at a +30 ?F suction temperature. Nine evaporative air-units operate at a +15 ?F suction temperature. Five evaporative air-units operate at a -20 ?F suction temperature using the two-stage intercooler as a re-circulator vessel. Six evaporative air-units operate at a -42 ?F suction temperature.

The ammonia piping and valves in the system are labeled. The identification system is recognized by IIAR. P&ID prints are available for review. Pipe, fittings, and connections specifications for ammonia refrigeration systems shall meet or exceed ASME/ANSI B31.5 specifications.

MITIGATION MEASURES
There are some mitigating measures in place. The location of the ammonia vessels is outside the building. Ammonia leak detection is installed in in the compressor room that sounds alarms and starts emergency ventilation. The emergency ventilation is automatically controlled and discharges the engine room air through the roof, which creates a lower level of concentration in the engine room for responders. It also starts air dispersion at lower concentration levels and disperses the ammonia with greater air turbulence. 

HAZARD ASSESSMENT
The hazard assessment was conducted to meet the RMP Off-site Consequence Analysis requirements for the ammonia refrigeration system. The only RMP regulated substance at this facility is anhydrous ammonia, which is classified is as a toxic substance, liquefied under pressure. The definitions and parameters for the release scenarios are based on the "Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration" as described in Chapter 4: Off-site Consequence Analysis.

ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM
This facility follows the OSHA Process Safety Management Program. Various special elements have been incor

porated into this program to meet the additional EPA requirements for the RMP. Following is an overview.

Participation - The Participation Program is an asset to both employees at the site and to the community as a whole.  As a general rule, employees who are fully involved have a greater sense of responsibility; they are more likely to catch the problems that can cause accidents. Employee awareness is for all employees, not directly involved with the process, this includes knowing the hazards, the safety rules, warning signs, and evacuation procedures. All employees have access to the Process Safety Management Program. Involved employees participate directly in every phrase of the PSM program, including conducting the PHA, developing or reviewing operating procedures, reviewing incident investigations, and conducting mechanical integrity and compliance audits. Community involvement is through coordination, cooperation, and pre-planning with the local Fire department and LEPC.

Process Safety Information - Process Safety Information includes a wide variety of books, manuals, and process information. These are available to employees that operate, maintain, or repair the process equipment or piping. There are three major categories of information: ammonia data such as MSDS, safety information, first aid, chemical properties, IIAR safety bulletins, etc.; process information such as piping & instrumentation diagrams (P&ID's), block flow diagram, mass flow balance, design codes and standards, pressure safety relief settings, safety system/devices, ventilation system design, operating procedures, safe operating limits, and ramification of process deviation; and process equipment information such as equipment specifications, electrical classifications, materials of construction, installation manuals, operating and maintenance manuals, and manufacturer's manuals.

Process Hazard Analysis - A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was completed using the "What-if" technique.  This a

ddressed hazards, engineering and administrative controls, consequences of failure of engineering and administrative controls, facility siting, human factors, and a qualitative evaluation of the possible safety and health impact. The results of the PHA were prioritized and incorporated into a PHA Findings Report for follow-up as a corrective action log.

Standard Operating Procedures - SOPs are provided for each compressor, condenser, ammonia vessel and oil pot, and evaporator. Topics include general information such items as objectives, hazards, location, equipment needed, P&ID's, task flow diagrams, and step-by-step procedures with specific warnings and comments. The SOPs cover different phases of operations such as: initial startup; normal, temporary and emergency operations; emergency shutdowns; and startup following a shutdown.

Training - All employees are who are involved with anhydrous ammonia have been properly trained, at a minimum, in understanding the MSDS, routine refrigeration system operation, emergency refrigeration system operation, emergency and normal refrigeration safety practices, and, if appropriate, the individual's role in the emergency response plan.

Contractors - This site follows strict guidelines for qualifying contractors who directly influence the safety of the process or the system. The contractor qualification procedure ensures that contractors and their employees are fully aware of the potential dangers involved with the ammonia process that contractors understand their responsibility and train their people, and that a contractor's safety record is considered in reviewing the bids. 

Pre-Startup Review - Pre-startup safety reviews are required on all new or modified equipment/systems. This involves process safety information, process hazard analysis, training, safety procedures, operating procedures, and verification that construction and equipment are in accord with the design specifications.

Mechanical Integrity Audits - The purp

ose of the Mechanical Integrity Audit program is to ensure that the equipment is maintained in good working condition.  These are performed on all compressors, condensers, evaporators, pressure vessels, piping system, relief and vent systems and devices, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps.

Hot Work Permits - This permit process is to protect against fire, explosion and other dangers resulting from hot work (welding and cutting outside the designated areas).  Hot work permits must be obtained before any work is done outside the shop area. The Maintenance Supervisor reviews and issues the permits to insure all fire prevention and protection rules are met. Permits indicate the appropriate dates and the work to be done. The permits are kept on file until workers have completed the hot work operations.

Management of Change - The Management of Change (MOC) procedure requires that all changes (even "replacement in kind") be reviewed to see if there is a possible negative effect. The MOC review addresses the technical basis for the change, the impact on safety and health, modifications to operating procedures, and authorization requirements for the proposed change.  Employees affected by the change are informed of the change before startup and trained in the proper procedures.

Incident Investigation - An incident investigation shall be performed any time there is an incident which resulted in, or which could reasonably have resulted in, a catastrophic release of ammonia. The purpose is to gain information that could prevent further accidents and to identify weaknesses in the emergency response plan that need to be addressed. Investigations are initiated promptly using a trained team. The findings and recommendations will be studied and appropriate corrective action taken.

Emergency Response Plan - This facility has a comprehensive emergency response plan that meets established criteria.  This plan will be provided to the local fire department and the Local

Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).

Compliance Audits and RMP Revisions - To insure that all areas of PSM and RMP programs are followed, the company requires compliance audits.  At a minimum, these must be completed every three years. Resubmission of the RMP shall be done every five years to meet the OCA requirements.

ACCIDENT HISTORY - LAST FIVE YEARS
This is a new facility. There have been no RMP reportable accidents within the past five years.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
None at this time. This is a new facility.
